Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 11:51AM Artemis wrote: I am so sorry you had to go through that, tracyanne.  That's so wrong, and I think you should definitely talk to your BS about it.  You might save a sister down the road from having the same problems. I had morphine in the recovery room.  Once I was back in my room, I had Demerol.  I could choose 50mg by mouth or 75 mg by IV; the nurses let me choose which I wanted each time.  Unfortunately, I ended up having a reaction to Demerol the next morning and had to go on Darvocet anyway (I'm allergic to Lortab and Percocet), but in your case, you should have had stronger meds. I know hospitals have to have certain policies, but that thing with the pump sounds ridiculous.  Perhaps some letters to the hospital board could help remedy this situation.  A doctor leaves an order, but the nurses aren't allowed to follow it?  Please. Best wishes to you, Artemis

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 08:27PM - edited Jan 17, 2012 08:29PM by Artemis Hi, rabbit ~ I was in pretty much the same situation, and I decided against having more nodes removed.  I had only 1mm of micromets, and I was going to have rads anyway because I was Grade 3.   The BS wanted to cut; MO and RO thoughts rads would be enough.  With two of three doctors agreeing, and with my VERY high fear of lymphedema, I went with just rads.  FOR ME, this was a good decision because even if the nodes were removed there was no guarantee that the cancer wouldn't come back. Since then (June 2009) I've had four scares of recurrence, but I don't regret not having the extra surgery.  As I said, it was a good decision FOR ME, and I'm at peace with it.      I wish I could give you a definitive answer.  I wish we could know that doing this, that and the other would be a sure thing.  But that's just not the way it is for us.  I'm very sorry that you're facing this, and I pray you can reach a decision with which you're comfortable. Love, Artemis
Posts.Title: Remove the rest of the lymph nodes or rely on rads? rabbit Artemis

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 12:19PM Artemis wrote: Hi, jennywong ~ I'm not Ellen, but I can tell you that I had chemo before surgery because my cancer was Grade 3.  This means it's growing very fast, so some oncologists give chemotherapy first in that case. Since Ellen is Grade 3, too, I'm guessing that's the reason she had chemo first.   Did you have the Oncotype test or are you saying the BS has just suggested it?  What does your oncologist say? Artemis
Posts.Title: Remove the rest of the lymph nodes or rely on rads? rabbit Artemis

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 02:21PM - edited Jan 20, 2012 02:24PM by Artemis lago ~ Well, I didn't have mets and we didn't know about my one node until after surgery (all the scans showed negative nodes), so if there was some other reason besides my Grade 3, I don't know what it is. And I didn't say that everyone with Grade 3 has chemo first.  I said >>some oncologists give chemotherapy first in that case.>> All I know is I saw the BS first, he said he thought I should see the onc and have chemo first because the cancer was Grade 3.  I saw the onc, he agreed with the surgeon, and I had chemo before surgery.   Artemis

Posts.Content: May 11, 2013 07:31PM Artemis wrote: Hi, Sophie ~ I had very large fibrocysitic breasts.  If I kept the non-cancerous one, my surgeon wanted me to have a mammogram, then six monthes later an MRI, then six months later a mammogram, then six months later an MRI....and on and on and on, plus I'd probably be having lots of biopsies due to questionable cysts.  And I thought it might be difficult to have all that weight pulling on the one shoulder. So after much weeping, wailing, praying, mind-changing, more weeping and wailing, I opted to have a double mastectomy.  It wasn't an easy decision, and I won't say I'm "happy" with my choice, but I believe I made the right one FOR ME.  I was 46 at the time.   I haven't had reconstruction, but am considering it. Best wishes! Artemis

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 12:05AM Artemis wrote: Hi, Sunshine ~ Are you aware that the more nodes you have out, the more you may be at risk for lymphedema?  That's something else you might want to consider.  Of course, have "only 2" nodes out doesn't mean we won't develop lymphedema at some point, but it's still something to think about. I hope I don't sound as if I'm trying to talk you out of the surgery because I'm not doing that at all.  I just want to help you look all options and considerations. Artemis

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 01:53PM Artemis wrote: Hi, javagirl ~ Of course you're terrified!  This is a very scary thing, and "staying positive" isn't going to make it less scary.  I know the people who say things like "stay positive" and "be strong" to you mean well, but unless they've been there they just don't understand.   As for how to get through the wait, posting and reading here helped me.  Plus, I've been de-cluttering my house.  During the times when I could only pace because I was so nervous, I'd pick up something that didn't belong in whatever room I was pacing through at the time.  When I'd pace my way to the proper room, I'd put that away that item and pick up something else.  Sounds funny, I know, but hey...my house is a lot neater now!  Hugs to you, Artemis

Posts.Content: Artemis wrote: Hello, Everyone ~ First off:  I don't have LE, I have a sleeve ordered, and I've learned massage and wrapping from a therapist. I don't like flying in general because I tend to panic if I feel that I'm in a place where I can't leave if I want to.  I have Xanax to help with that, so I think I can deal with flying except... ...I'm afraid of lymphedma.  So, my question is, how reliable are sleeves and wrapping for prevention when flying?  I was reading some other threads, and several of you ladies mentioned the need for a glove as well as the sleeve.  Should I tell my therapist I want one?  She said to use the sleeve and bandages for flying; she never mentioned a glove. I'm trying to decide if this trip if worth the risk.  Honestly, it's not really worth it to me, but it means a great deal to my husband and other family members.  On the other hand (heh..), they will not be the ones having to massage and bandage if LE develops. So, do you know of anyone who got LE after flying even if she wore a sleeve and bandages?  Thanks so much! Artemis DD ACx4, Tx4. BMX 6/1/2009. Tamoxifen: 2009-. Rads 28/28. Herceptin 18/18 Dx 1/6/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Hormonal Therapy 6/15/2009 Targeted Therapy Herceptin (trastuzumab) Radiation Therapy Chemotherapy AC + T (Taxol) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Afraid To Fly Artemis mumito

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 09:13PM Artemis wrote: I had mammogram, ultrasound, core biopsy, MRI and PET scan in that order.  If was after the PET showed no cancer in the nodes that my onco put me at stage 2.  The treatment plan was put together after the MRI; I'm having chemo, then surgery. Hugs to you and your mother, Artemis
Posts.Title: How much testing did you go through before you were staged? ilmm99 Artemis

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 01:22AM Artemis wrote: Oh, LindaLou, I am literally in tears over your post.  (Yes, I tend to overreact at times, lol)  Since I started on this journey in January, I've had my eye on football season.  That was the goal (no pun intended):  I'd be finished with treatment by the time football season came, and I've been so looking forward to it.  Life would then be back to somewhat normal. And then I found out about LE, and I've been so scared ever since. Your advice is terrific and makes me believe I just might can do this!  Thank you, thank you, thank you! Artemis
Posts.Title: Avoiding LE in my state's heat/humidity Artemis kira

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 12:46PM Artemis wrote: Thank you, MOTC.  You're right; I have been giving it too much power by letting it terrify me.  On the other hand, I do realize that no matter how hard we try, some of us are just going to get it anyway.  You wonderful ladies are helping me find the balance between these two ways of thinking, and I truly appreciate you. I'm so thankful for this website.  It not for it and its members, I'd know nothing about LE since none of my doctors or nurses have mentioned it to me. Hugs to all, Artemis
Posts.Title: Avoiding LE in my state's heat/humidity Artemis kira

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 04:13PM - edited Sep 28, 2009 05:22PM by Artemis Thank you, everyone, for your replies. If only my head wouldn't start pounding when thinking of wrapping and flying and sleeves, oh my!...then I might could actually figure out what to do.   I feel like it's going to come down to the fact that I don't want to fly.  Period.  The risk isn't worth it.  If I get LE from this trip, I can't imagine I'd say, "Well, I have LE, but it's worth it because I got to (fill in the blank.)"  There are situations that I think would be worth it, but not this one. Hugs to all, Artemis

Posts.Content: Artemis wrote: Hello, Everyone ~ I've been reading here for some time and have learned much from this forum.  Now I come to ask some questions. I know that "extreme temperature" can trigger LE.  I know that activities should be done in cooler parts of the day whenever possible.  However...I have season tickets for the University of MyState's football games.   Game days in my southern US state are HOT and HUMID.  The temps are usually around 95 degrees with very high humidity.  Games last 3-4 hours.  Most kickoffs are between noon and 3:00. Even pre-BC, I made sure to stay hydrated at these games, and this year my seats are in the shade which will help a great deal.   So my questions are:  should I think about getting LE sleeves before the season starts?  How good are they at actual prevention?  Might I be ok to not wear sleeves?  Or am I a fool to try going at all? Thanks so much, and hugs to all. Artemis DD ACx4, Tx4. BMX 6/1/2009. Tamoxifen: 2009-. Rads 28/28. Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 05:43PM Artemis wrote: Ok, I bought a Target cami which was a little bit loose, and then I stuffed my fiberfill foobies into it.  The whole bra part fell forward, so I'm going to exchange it for a smaller size. Once I figure out what size really works, I'm gonna order some of the scoop neck ones from the website.  (Wonder why the stores are carrying only the v-necks?) I'm also looking at the microbead forms at TLCDirect.  Thank you, Coonie, for starting this thread, and thanks to the rest of you ladies for your input!  I don't like the bras or forms that I have, so I'm always on the lookout for something better. I do have a sports bra that sounds like the one faithandfifty mentioned, and I like it pretty well.  It has slightly molded cups into which I may or may not have been known to stuff a pair of trouser socks.
